channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. UK Remote Perl Role.
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Our client provides online trading services and with offices in Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia, they’ve got the global reach that may provide the challenge you’re looking for. For the right person, they’ve got a work-sponsored visa and relocation package — if you’ve got the expertise and an adventurous spirit, they’ve got the will and means to get you where you need to be.

item.title: Modern Perl and positive team vibes. UK Remote Perl role
item.description: If you’re a Modern Perl developer in the UK with Go-lang experience (or at least a strong desire to learn) and you’re searching for a team of dynamos, we’ve found the perfect place for you. This award-winning company may be newer, but the combined experience of their people is impressive. No doubt this is one of the many reasons their AI recruitment marketing business has taken off!

item.title: The latest Perl-related posts on DEV
item.description: Which articles did you like?

item.title: PWC 192
item.description: Loved the discussion of "Equal Distribution" task. Enjoy behind the scene story.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 192
item.description: As always, we got Perl and Python together playing with bits. Well done.

item.title: Equal Flips For All
item.description: Javascript bit operation in play this week. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Flipping easy and distributing fairly
item.description: Pure discussion of task, just like story telling. You really don't want to skip it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 192
item.description: This week task fits in one-liner as far as Perl is concerned. Great work.

item.title: distribute and flip
item.description: Special one-liner in Raku is not to be nissed. Well done. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 192: Binary Flip and Equal Distribution
item.description: Laurent's ability to make difficult task easy is worth watching. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Counter to Equilibrium
item.description: Pure mathematical solution, very nice attempt. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 192
item.description: Loved the different ways to deal with bits. Enough to keep you busy. Highly Recommended.

item.title: PWC192 - Equal Distribution
item.description: Task analysis made it so simple to follow. Implementation in Perl and Raku is also fun to watch.

item.title: PWC192 - Binary Flip
item.description: Bitwise operation in full play in Perl and Raku. Nice work.

item.title: Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité
item.description: Colin's style of task analysis opens up new angle to it. Highly recommended.

item.title: Frosting a cake without flipping the spatula
item.description: Plenty of different approaches discussed from the performance point of view. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Flipped Equilibrium
item.description: Cool discussion of the task and solutions in Perl, Raku and Haskell. Worth checking it out. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Flipping to Redistribute
item.description: Playing with raw bits makes it fun. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 192
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Binary Flip" and "Equal Distribution" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 193
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Binary String" and "Odd String". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Playing with MQTT
item.description: Do you know MQTT? I didn't. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Advent of Code 2022 is coming
item.description: Never played with Advent of Code. If time permits, I will give it a go. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: An objective criteria for deprecating community platforms
item.description: Take a look at the history of community platforms. Interesting ...

item.title: Speaking of certificates and Root CAs...
Two-factor authentication (2FA) in Perl with TOTP algorithm (Microsoft or Google Authenticator or others)
item.description: Get the insights of 2FA and how Perl can help you deal with it.

item.title: Personalized investment with Torto AI
item.description: Any investment in the stock market is partially based on objective data (e.g. P/E ratio) and partially on the subjective world-view of the investor (expected changes in inflation, politics, weather etc.) torto.ai works on providing you a platform where you can easily combine these aspects and find the investment that most suitable for your expectation.

item.title: This Week in PSC (088)
item.description: Brief update about the Perl Steering Council latest meetup.

item.title: #592 - Perl Blogging?
item.description:
Hi there,

We all know not many people blog about Perl anymore. Are we doing anything to get it back on track? Well, unfortunately again, nothing is happening on that front either.

But, hey, there is still hope and handful of Perl fans doing their best. One of them is our chief editor, Gabor Szabo. He has been running Perl Maven for years now and many of us benefitted from his work. He recently started blogging on Dev.To. I request all the Perl fans to follow him and like blog post. I didn't have the account there before so I decided to create personal account. Although I no longer blog at all but this is going to change soon. Earlier I used to blog on blogs.perl.org but then I moved to The Weekly Challenge recently.

Talking about blogging, how can I miss one name, Flavio Poletti? He has been blogging daily for years now. Feel free to check out his work here. Kudos to him for his effort.

I would like to mention another name, Olaf Alders, for his hard work in reviving the good old friend, Perl Advent Calendar. Julien has been helping him in the project too. I remember there was a call for papers by him. If you have time and something to share about your favourite CPAN module then please do contribute. I have booked one slot for myself for this year Advent Calendar. Hopefully, I will submit my article on time.

Last but not the least, I would like to thank all the members of Team PWC for creating friendly and positive vibes for years now. As of today, they have published 3000+ blog posts sharing creative ideas and solutions. If you are interested then please do checkout blog posts.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
